document.title: Illinois Learning Standards for Social Science

9A63D540DFE5013173AB68A86D17958E.description: Describe how individuals interacted within groups to make choices regarding food, clothing and shelter.

9A638F30DFE5013173AA68A86D17958E.description: Understand how social systems form and develop over time.

9A634430DFE5013173A968A86D17958E.description: Identify major social institutions in the community.

9A62FAD0DFE5013173A868A86D17958E.description: Compare the roles of individuals in group situations (e.g., student, committee member, employee/employer).

9A629C20DFE5013173A768A86D17958E.description: Understand the roles and interactions of individuals and groups in society.

9A624A40DFE5013173A668A86D17958E.description: Identify folklore from different cultures which became part of the heritage of the United States.

9A620660DFE5013173A568A86D17958E.description: Compare characteristics of culture as reflected in language, literature, the arts, traditions and institutions.

9A61BDA0DFE5013173A468A86D17958E.description: Understand social systems, with an emphasis on the United States.
comments: A study of social systems has two important aspects that help people understand their roles as individuals and members of society. The first aspect is culture consisting of the language, literature, arts and traditions of various groups of people. Students should understand common characteristics of different cultures and explain how cultural contributions shape societies over time. The second aspect is the interaction among individuals, groups and institutions. Students should know how and why groups and institutions are formed, what roles they play in society, and how individuals and groups interact with and influence institutions.

9A617370DFE5013173A368A86D17958E.description: Identify changes in geographic characteristics of a local region (e.g., town, community).

9A610E00DFE5013173A268A86D17958E.description: Understand the historical significance of geography.

9A60AC50DFE5013173A168A86D17958E.description: Explain the difference between renewable and nonrenewable resources.

9A605C50DFE5013173A068A86D17958E.description: Identify opportunities and constraints of the physical environment.

9A601260DFE50131739F68A86D17958E.description: Identify ways people depend on and interact with the physical environment (e.g., farming, fishing, hydroelectric power).

9A5FCA40DFE50131739E68A86D17958E.description: Understand relationships between geographic factors and society.

9A5F46B0DFE50131739C68A86D17958E.description: Identify components of the Earth's physical systems.

9A5F0180DFE50131739B68A86D17958E.description: Analyze and explain characteristics and interactions of the Earth's physical systems.

9A5EB280DFE50131739A68A86D17958E.description: Identify the characteristics and purposes of geographic representations including maps, globes, graphs, photographs, software, digital images and be able to locate specific places using each.

9A5E6BC0DFE50131739968A86D17958E.description: Identify physical characteristics of places, both local and global (e.g., locations, roads, regions, bodies of water).

9A5E1C40DFE50131739868A86D17958E.description: Locate, describe and explain places, regions and features on the Earth.

9A5DCB80DFE50131739768A86D17958E.description: Understand world geography and the effects of geography on society, with an emphasis on the United States.
comments: The need for geographic literacy has never been greater or more obvious than in today's tightly interrelated world. Students must understand the world's physical features, how they blend with social systems and how they affect economies, politics and human interaction. Isolated geographic facts are not enough. To grasp geography and its effect on individuals and societies, students must know the broad concepts of spatial patterns, mapping, population and physical systems (land, air, water). The combination of geographic facts and broad concepts provides a deeper understanding of geography and its effects on individuals and societies.

9A5D7A10DFE50131739668A86D17958E.description: Compare depictions of the natural environment that are found in myths, legends, folklore and traditions.

9A5D3220DFE50131739568A86D17958E.description: Describe how the local environ-ment has changed over time.

9A5CE8E0DFE50131739468A86D17958E.description: Understand Illinois, United States and world environmental history.

9A5CA770DFE50131739368A86D17958E.description: Identify how customs and traditions from around the world influence the local community.

9A5C6260DFE50131739268A86D17958E.description: Describe key figures and organizations (e.g., fraternal/civic organizations, public service groups, community leaders) in the social history of the local community.

9A5C1970DFE50131739168A86D17958E.description: Understand Illinois, United States and world social history.

9A5BD160DFE50131739068A86D17958E.description: Explain how trade among people brought an exchange of ideas, technology and language.

9A5B6DC0DFE50131738F68A86D17958E.description: Identify how people and groups in the past made economic choices (e.g., crops to plant, products to make, products to trade) to survive and improve their lives.

9A5B1670DFE50131738E68A86D17958E.description: Explain how the economy of the students' local community has changed over time.

9A5AD700DFE50131738D68A86D17958E.description: Describe how Native American people in Illinois engaged in economic activities with other tribes and traders in the region prior to the Black Hawk War.

9A5A98D0DFE50131738C68A86D17958E.description: Understand the development of economic systems.

9A5A59D0DFE50131738B68A86D17958E.description: Explain the contributions of individuals and groups who are featured in biographies, legends, folklore and traditions.

9A5A1910DFE50131738A68A86D17958E.description: Explain why individuals, groups, issues and events are celebrated with local, state or national holidays or days of recognition (e.g., Lincoln's Birthday, Martin Luther King's Birthday, Pulaski Day, Fourth of July, Memorial Day, Labor Day, Veterans' Day, Thanksgiving).

9A59D750DFE50131738968A86D17958E.description: Identify key individuals and events in the development of the local community (e.g., Founders days, names of parks, streets, public buildings).

9A599100DFE50131738868A86D17958E.description: Understand the development of significant political events.

9A5942F0DFE50131738768A86D17958E.description: Describe how people in different times and places viewed the world in different ways.

9A590220DFE50131738668A86D17958E.description: Ask historical questions and seek out answers from historical sources (e.g., myths, biographies, stories, old photographs, artwork, other visual or electronic sources).

9A58C1A0DFE50131738568A86D17958E.description: Explain the difference between past, present and future time; place themselves in time.

9A5880A0DFE50131738468A86D17958E.description: Apply the skills of historical analysis and interpretation.

9A583D80DFE50131738368A86D17958E.description: Understand events, trends, individuals and movements shaping the history of Illinois, the United States and other nations.
comments: George Santayana said "those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it." In a broader sense, students who can examine and analyze the events of the past have a powerful tool for understanding the events of today and the future. They develop an understanding of how people, nations, actions and interactions have led to today's realities. In the process, they can better define their own roles as participating citizens.

9A57FA10DFE50131738268A86D17958E.description: Identify goods and services provided by government.

9A57B1C0DFE50131738168A86D17958E.description: Understand the impact of government policies and decisions on production and consumption in the economy.

9A576240DFE50131738068A86D17958E.description: Know that barter is a type of exchange and that money makes exchange easier.

9A571E40DFE50131737F68A86D17958E.description: Demonstrate the benefits of simple voluntary exchanges.

9A56DA60DFE50131737E68A86D17958E.description: Understand trade as an exchange of goods or services.

9A5691E0DFE50131737D68A86D17958E.description: Identify limitations in resources that force producers to make choices about what to produce.

9A563790DFE50131737C68A86D17958E.description: Describe how human, natural and capital resources are used to produce goods and services.

9A55E1D0DFE50131737B68A86D17958E.description: Understand that scarcity necessitates choices by producers.

9A558A30DFE50131737A68A86D17958E.description: Explain why consumers must make choices.

9A5542E0DFE50131737968A86D17958E.description: Understand that scarcity necessitates choices by consumers.

9A550000DFE50131737868A86D17958E.description: Describe how wages/salaries can be earned in exchange for work.

9A54BD50DFE50131737768A86D17958E.description: Identify advantages and disadvantages of different ways to distribute goods and services.

9A5477A0DFE50131737668A86D17958E.description: Understand how different economic systems operate in the exchange, production, distribution and consumption of goods and services.

9A542890DFE50131737568A86D17958E.description: Understand economic systems, with an emphasis on the United States.
comments: Why This Goal Is Important: People's lives are directly affected by the economies of cities, states, nations and the world. All people engage in economic activity: buying, selling, trading, producing and consuming. By understanding economic systems-and how economics blends with other social sciences, students will be able to make more informed choices, prudently use resources and function as effective participants in the economies around them.

9A53E040DFE50131737468A86D17958E.description: Describe political ideas and traditions important to the development of the United States including democracy, individual rights and the concept of freedom.

9A53A2A0DFE50131737368A86D17958E.description: Understand the development of United States political ideas and traditions.

9A5364C0DFE50131737268A86D17958E.description: Identify relationships that the federal government establishes with other nations.

9A5326F0DFE50131737168A86D17958E.description: Understand United States foreign policy as it relates to other nations and international issues.

9A52E900DFE50131737068A86D17958E.description: Identify the roles of civic leaders (e.g., elected leaders, public service leaders).

9A52AA20DFE50131736F68A86D17958E.description: Understand the roles and influences of individuals and interest groups in the political systems of Illinois, the United States and other nations.

9A526730DFE50131736E68A86D17958E.description: Identify concepts of responsible citizenship including respect for the law, patriotism, civility and working with others.

9A521410DFE50131736D68A86D17958E.description: Understand election processes and responsibilities of citizens.

9A51C440DFE50131736C68A86D17958E.description: Identify the different levels of government as local, state and national.

9A517760DFE50131736B68A86D17958E.description: Understand the structures and functions of the political systems of Illinois, the United States and other nations.

9A512A80DFE50131736A68A86D17958E.description: Describe the fundamental principles of government including representative government, government of law, individual rights and the common good.

9A50E050DFE50131736968A86D17958E.description: Understand and explain basic principles of the United States government.

9A508BE0DFE50131736868A86D17958E.description: Understand political systems, with an emphasis on the United States.
comments: The existence and advancement of a free society depend on the knowledge, skills and understanding of its citizenry. Through the study of various forms and levels of government and the documents and institutions of the United States, students will develop the skills and knowledge that they need to be contributing citizens, now and in the future.
